headline: Chevron, Exxon earnings: M&A in focus amid low oil prices
summary: Exxon (XOM) and Chevron (CVX) are in focus after releasing quarterly earnings results. Both energy giants are making strategic acquisitions as oil prices (CL=F, BZ=F) are low. Hedgeye Risk Management energy analyst Fernando Valle joins Market Catalysts to discuss the energy giants' merger and acquisition (M&A) strategies. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Market Catalysts.

headline: Exxon Crushes Q3 Forecasts on Record Guyana and Permian Output
summary: Exxon Mobil exceeded third-quarter earnings forecasts, reporting $8.1 billion in adjusted earnings due to record output from Guyana and the Permian Basin, while also boosting its dividend and progressing the Rovuma LNG project.

headline: Profits dip at ExxonMobil, Chevron on lower crude prices
summary: US oil giants ExxonMobil and Chevron reported lower earnings Friday as the decline in oil prices offset the lift from higher production.The results showed the impact on earnings from crude oil prices in the $60-$70 per-barrel range, down about $10 from the 2024 period.

content.title: Profits dip at ExxonMobil, Chevron on lower crude prices
content.summary: US oil giants ExxonMobil and Chevron reported lower earnings Friday as the decline in oil prices offset the lift from higher production.The results showed the impact on earnings from crude oil prices in the $60-$70 per-barrel range, down about $10 from the 2024 period.

headline: Exxon, Chevron Earnings Fall as Output Climbs And Prices Drop
summary: Exxon Mobil and Chevron posted lower third-quarter earnings Friday but said they will continue to ratchet up production even as oil prices languish near $60 a barrel.  Shares in Exxon edged higher, while Chevron stock added more than 3% in afternoon trading.  Exxon’s quarterly profit came in at $7.5 billion, down 12% from the same period a year ago.

content.title: Exxon, Chevron Earnings Fall as Output Climbs And Prices Drop
content.summary: Exxon Mobil and Chevron posted lower third-quarter earnings Friday but said they will continue to ratchet up production even as oil prices languish near $60 a barrel.  Shares in Exxon edged higher, while Chevron stock added more than 3% in afternoon trading.  Exxon’s quarterly profit came in at $7.5 billion, down 12% from the same period a year ago.

headline: Exxon and Chevron Cut Divergent Paths as Global Oil Glut Looms
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp. is pressing ahead with a raft of expansion projects, even as OPEC and its allies increase production and oil futures hover near a four-year low.  Chevron Corp. meanwhile is positioning itself to wring cash from existing operations to weather the market downturn.  In the short term, investors are applauding Chevron’s approach, bidding its stock up as much as 3.5% Friday after both companies reported third-quarter results that exceeded Wall Street’s expectations.

content.title: Exxon and Chevron Cut Divergent Paths as Global Oil Glut Looms
content.summary: Exxon Mobil Corp. is pressing ahead with a raft of expansion projects, even as OPEC and its allies increase production and oil futures hover near a four-year low.  Chevron Corp. meanwhile is positioning itself to wring cash from existing operations to weather the market downturn.  In the short term, investors are applauding Chevron’s approach, bidding its stock up as much as 3.5% Friday after both companies reported third-quarter results that exceeded Wall Street’s expectations.

headline: Chevron Earnings Surprise the Street as Oil Price Falls
summary: Chevron  is weathering a slide in the price of oil better than Wall Street expected, its latest results show.  For the third quarter,  Chevron’s  adjusted earnings of $1.85 a share topped the $1.71 analysts had anticipated, according to FactSet.  Total revenue climbed to $49.73 billion in the quarter, surpassing forecasts of $47.23 billion, even though the price of oil has dropped about 13% on the year to a recent $65 per barrel.

content.title: Chevron Earnings Surprise the Street as Oil Price Falls
content.summary: Chevron  is weathering a slide in the price of oil better than Wall Street expected, its latest results show.  For the third quarter,  Chevron’s  adjusted earnings of $1.85 a share topped the $1.71 analysts had anticipated, according to FactSet.  Total revenue climbed to $49.73 billion in the quarter, surpassing forecasts of $47.23 billion, even though the price of oil has dropped about 13% on the year to a recent $65 per barrel.

headline: Exxon Mobil (XOM) Q3 2025 Earnings Call Transcript
summary: From the technologies we are deploying to the major projects we are delivering to the structural cost savings we are capturing and the value we are creating, our results are truly in a league of their own.  It is our fourth and largest development with a production capacity of 250,000 barrels per day.  Yellowtail was delivered in nearly the same time as previous FPSOs despite a 70% increase in facility weight from its higher production capacity and improvements in GHG performance.

content.title: Exxon Mobil (XOM) Q3 2025 Earnings Call Transcript
content.summary: From the technologies we are deploying to the major projects we are delivering to the structural cost savings we are capturing and the value we are creating, our results are truly in a league of their own.  It is our fourth and largest development with a production capacity of 250,000 barrels per day.  Yellowtail was delivered in nearly the same time as previous FPSOs despite a 70% increase in facility weight from its higher production capacity and improvements in GHG performance.

headline: Exxon Raises its Dividend. Why the Stock Is Falling Anyway.
summary: Exxon Mobil  beat third-quarter earnings expectations and raised its dividend on Friday.  Exxon’s  profits declined to $7.55 billion from $8.61 billion because the price of crude weakened.  Oil futures are off 16% this year, and falling prices have weighed on Exxon’s results.

headline: Global Oil Supply Will Keep Growing, Goldman Says
summary: Goldman Sachs Head of Oil Research Daan Struyven says the global oil supply will keep growing. He says oil prices could drop by another $10 per barrel over the next year. Oil giants Exxon Mobil and Chevron both beat Wall Street expectations on earnings. He speaks on "Bloomberg Surveillance."

headline: Amazon surges, Apple earnings, Chevron & Exxon: 3 Things
summary: US stock futures (ES=F, NQ=F, YM=F) are rising in Friday's pre-market trading, after a busy earnings week from Big Tech. Amazon (AMZN) shares are seeing gains of over 13% this morning after outpacing third quarter earnings and revenue estimates, bolstered by growth in its AWS (Amazon Web Services) cloud business. Apple (AAPL) stock is getting a slight lift as it forecasts strong holiday sales, as the iPhone maker also blew past Wall Street expectations for its fiscal fourth quarter. Exxon Mobil (XOM) stock ticks lower while Chevron's (CVX) moves higher after the oil producers reported their respective quarterly results. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Morning Brief.

content.title: Amazon surges, Apple earnings, Chevron & Exxon: 3 Things
content.description:
US stock futures (ES=F, NQ=F, YM=F) are rising in Friday's pre-market trading, after a busy earnings week from Big Tech. Amazon (AMZN) shares are seeing gains of over 13% this morning after outpacing third quarter earnings and revenue estimates, bolstered by growth in its AWS (Amazon Web Services) cloud business.

Apple (AAPL) stock is getting a slight lift as it forecasts strong holiday sales, as the iPhone maker also blew past Wall Street expectations for its fiscal fourth quarter.

Exxon Mobil (XOM) stock ticks lower while Chevron's (CVX) moves higher after the oil producers reported their respective quarterly results.

To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Morning Brief.

headline: Exxon posts strong quarterly earnings with production in Guyana and the Permian Basin picking up
summary: Exxon Mobil reported strong a strong third-quarter performance Friday, bolstered by strong Guyana and Permian Basin production.  Exxon earned $7.55 billion, or $1.76 per share, for the period ended Sept. 30.  Removing one time costs and benefits, earnings were $1.88 per share, which topped the $1.81 per share that Wall Street was looking for, according to a survey by Zacks Investment Research.

Exxon earned $7.55 billion, or $1.76 per share, for the period ended Sept. 30.  Removing one time costs and benefits, earnings were $1.88 per share, which topped the $1.81 per share that Wall Street was looking for, according to a survey by Zacks Investment Research.
